document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

A591AEB5758C4406941501048A2E3B5C.description:
Recognize that there are different types of energy (e.g.,
heat, electrical, sound, light, magnetic).

64A6E2E7C6254DEC820B17901A54CA83.description:
Identify objects that use different types of energy (e.g.,
heat, electrical, light, sound, magnetic).

1C8D52D611014EBDA729EC88CDC9C78A.description:
Identify when there is a change of energy (e.g., flipping
on a light, turning the volume up on a speaker, watching
a magnet move an object, lighting a candle and observing
heat and light).

1062B6439A2B4C8FB5C6856A640AB9FF.description: Match pictures to the type of energy depicted.

E8B065D718584B84900416C26861FFF3.description:
Demonstrate a way that energy can cause a change (e.g.,
dropping a ball in a bucket of sand, turning on a light,
turning on a fan, rice vibrating on the surface of a drum).

F9788FEBEB1A4BABA9647F36BF486EC1.description:
Identify
a change in energy
(e.g., a light turned
on after being
plugged in).

EDCA9F7378B34166BFDB2F2D842DF9BD.description:
Match a
type of energy to an
example of change
(e.g., light bulb
on, light bulb off -
electrical energy).

3B1A8FCE94F245658D9130E654B072E0.description:
Design a simple
experiment that
would show a form
of energy making a
change.

72EB752867BA4C0AB7CF06AC4341590F.description:
Explain
the difference
between two or
more types of
energy.

FC0514E14206496B9BC986B456BE0590.description:
Heat, electrical energy,
light, sound, and magnetic
energy are forms of energy.
There are many different
forms of energy. Energy is
the ability to cause motion or
create change. The different
forms of energy that are
outlined at this grade level
should be limited to familiar
forms that a student is able to
observe.

D42FF28A555E4EAAA39185E3F083EB6F.description:
Given objects, substances or pictures identify which are
solids, liquids and gases.

FAABED10F2E04AEDB9BEF0F10DEB9E54.description:
Recognize that different states of matter have different
properties (e.g., manipulate various materials to determine
how solids, liquids and gases differ.

C3E2A3EC64694847BCD4145E6475E0FB.description:
Given a situation identify whether something is being
heated or cooled (e.g., sun shining on a sidewalk, ice
cubes placed into water).

E5C6F4DF9C724761BF76EBB42A45F1D1.description:
Recognize that matter can change state when heated
(e.g., observe ice changing state from solid to liquid to
gas) or cooled (e.g., freeze water, watch condensation
form on a cold beverage).

A800AFF50CE6442C8BDC918117CAE39D.description:
Identify the changes that exist as a material heats or cools
(e.g., freezing, melting, boiling/evaporation, condensing).

C885557DAB8849F49E78859A60D1F5C5.description:
Match properties with states of matter (e.g., definite shape
with solid, fills any volume with gas).

9189455711EE47A081AA1857C15BF1BC.description:
Predict how various objects will change when heated or
cooled.

DB34C1B823324FB88FBE29F711B7B59F.description:
Identify
if something is
being heated or
cooled.

9C81860EC26749859E7CBF2F6A88624D.description:
Identify
an object as being
either a solid, a
liquid, or a gas.

14A859BF0A30475FBDB3290A407DC421.description:
Identify
how the state of
matter will change if a
substance is heated
or cooled.

B0AD4203CD934C59A4FF7D6C5F5574F4.description:
Identify
the possible states
of matter for a given
property (e.g., gas or
liquids can take the
shape of a container).

9C00FF72C6F04ACF9A5023DDB7B0A1CD.description:
Given a
substance, predict
how it will change
if heated or cooled.

A5B3235F52384D4DBD0E962C875F8B5F.description:
Match a
given property to
its state of matter.

3E9D9CA0A7B240F68563338854B296E7.description:
Matter exists in
different states, each of which
has different properties. The
most recognizable states
of matter are solids, liquids,
and gases. Shape and
compressibility are properties
that can distinguish between
the states of matter. One way
to change matter from one
state to another is by heating
or cooling.

1960C5ECFEEA4EBE92CB191A6F00C921.description:
Measure volume using nonstandard units (e.g., cubes,
marbles).Recognize that volume is the amount of space
taken up by an object or substance.

7F7AB9F6D21C49C080991E00870DEC39.description:
Measure volume using SI units (e.g., unit cubes,
milliliters).

F043DC53D9A44058B59777B892903270.description:
Recognize that mass is the amount of material in an object
or substance.

600060167F964C53875C80D0B7549F8B.description:
Measure mass using nonstandard units (e.g., paperclips,
washers, marbles).

94D026E89AD7464286EF4EAEA92D64DD.description: Measure mass using SI units (e.g., using a balance).

943812A6808D4DE295D0A24BFFDC013F.description:
Recognize that all matter (solids, liquids, gases) has
mass and volume. Note: Air having mass and volume was
explored in 2.ESS.1.

F3E33AA12E6340A28CD6BA7B0BD52646.description:
Compare the volume of two containers (e.g., which holds
more pieces of popcorn, which holds more milliliters of
water).

10A6D0681380498E893B4961FC60D402.description:
Compare objects of the same size and shape that have
different masses (e.g., by finding their mass or by lifting to
see which is heavier).

0DA207470CD448F9A9638B7E646CD8D8.description:
Identify
one or more
characteristics of
matter (takes up
space and has
mass).

7DF29A6B96C548F6B056814E0505C570.description:
Using
non-traditional
measurement, units
(e.g., paper clips,
cubes), identify the
volume or mass of an
object.

C16A249916C04AB8876075450E20916E.description:
Using
non-traditional
measurements,
measure the
volume of different
objects, and
using metric or
non-traditional
measurements,
measure the mass
of different objects.

AC7B8155928A4C3FA66D8ACF72374222.description:
All objects and
substances in the natural
world are composed of matter.
Matter takes up space and
has mass. Differentiating
between mass and weight is
not necessary at this grade
level.

A70C5546431742CDA1BE35677C27C4C3.description:
Recognize that organisms are born/germinate, grow,
reproduce, die and decay.

4B9AE4FF5DD04CDFB4CED850D8008573.description:
Identify different stages of a life cycle (e.g., watch nature
videos that trace the life cycles of a variety of organisms,
observe mealworms in the classroom).

EB455CEDDBE1462BA34FFDC91A267831.description:
Know that an individual organism may die at any point in
the life cycle.

FC79DED080424FFBBCB3BD77737B4873.description:
Match stage of the life cycle to what is going on in the
environment (e.g., many babies are born in the spring
when food is plentiful, seeds germinate when the soil is
moist).

4F107151941D435A96F13A53009F12BC.description:
Recognize that different organisms may have different life
stages (e.g., metamorphosis).

A929A0C0CDEA440092A56B07EB5496B6.description:
Identify
the main stages
of an organism’s
life cycle: birth,
growth, adulthood,
reproduction, and
death.

1B2F077AAF934F99AC174402A21B1D59.description:
Match an
organism’s life cycle
to an environment.

524A7AAF2B4048239A1CB86DF21CF135.description:
Describe
how a specific
environment
supports a specific
organism’s life
cycle (e.g.,
flowering plants do
not flower outside
in the winter).

DF55545C28954BC4B3DC0E9062BDF177.description:
Plants and animals
have life cycles that are part of
their adaptations for survival
in their natural environments.
Worldwide, organisms are
growing, reproducing, dying,
and decaying. The details of
the life cycle are different for
different organisms, which
affects their ability to survive
and reproduce in their natural
environments. Note: The
names of the stages within the
life cycles are not the focus.

963D9EE4D54949F98A5FA23965712CE3.description:
Using pictures or actual organisms identify differences
among traits in members of the same species (e.g., litter
of puppies have different coloration or fur texture).

FD136F49DA614ABC88A1866F3120EC0F.description:
Match organisms and the environment in which they are
found (e.g., fish in water, deer in forest).

2594CB26C9F84B8B9A979948ADD6F8BC.description:
Identify that variations in traits may provide a survival
advantage.

0A7C35CD3085457681D6F26785A152CB.description:
Describe the traits of an organism that help it live in its
environment (e.g., thick covering on cactus, thick fur on
Arctic animals, the ability to camouflage, fast running
speed of predators, ability to climb).

3ADF261410CF48BB9A2B19DDD0117A9D.description: Identify traits as advantageous in certain environments.

86E913AD9AC0495B925FD9AA4F82A715.description:
Explain why a particular trait is advantageous in a given
environment.

C2D16E11D39D4245BB62476FA56FB640.description:
Identify
traits in an
individual organism
that would help it
be successful in its
environment.

12BADF84F34E452BB450EF5D50763E23.description:
Identify
that there is
variation within the
same species.

A1B9EFF75ACA46D79268ECA89558C757.description:
When
given an environment
and given variations
of the same organism,
select the one
variation that will be
an advantage to the
organism.

969023F1F6BE4F7194BE96A0DBB645E3.description:
Identify
variations in physical
and behavioral traits
within the same
species.

F6D3F868B31248E1938D60FBE09CE75F.description:
Explain
why one physical
or behavioral trait
within a species
would be an
advantage in a
given environment.

D7A47B542DA3453082844BEBC936BA49.description:
Describe
how a variation
in a physical or
behavioral trait
would give an
individual an
advantage.

677F7B3D38D44E8F8F4E41FE1A66E797.description:
Individuals of the
same kind of organism
differ in their inherited traits.
These differences give some
individuals an advantage in
surviving and/or reproducing.
Plants and animals have
physical features that
are associated with the
environments where they
live. Plants and animals have
certain physical or behavioral
characteristics that influence
their chances of surviving in
particular environments. Note:
The focus is on the individual,
not the population. Adaption
is not the focus at this grade
level.

204C32E3686B4EB0A924E80815D160C5.description:
Match offspring to parents.Recognize that offspring look
like parents (e.g., kittens look like cats, small trees look
like bigger trees, children and adults have the same body
parts).

07BC5EE0949F47DDB9DC76901D51A1A0.description:
Describe similarities and differences in the appearance of
parents and offspring (e.g., dogs and puppies have fur but
puppy fur is softer).

AF22A8ACADFD4A85A0A57FEDA0AC81D3.description:
Describe the growth of a organism from birth to adulthood
and note the changes (e.g., watch a nesting webcam,
plant seedlings).

BE97DDC3A86A4B1CB2EC627820417324.description:
Explain that information that determines physical and
behavior traits is passed on from one generation to the
next.

AB170463B3DC4129A9942E07DFF64B5A.description: Know that some traits are inherited and some are learned.

B882309F53444A488468A6F61644B80D.description:
Give examples of behaviors that are not inherited but
are learned after birth (e.g., a bird learning to fly, children
learning to read, a lion learning to hunt).

69A2412464C745E58DAB506ECEBEA3E4.description: Classify a set of traits as learned or inherited.

56794D597D3E4DEF8305434EFD36DCE4.description:
Explain how learned behaviors help an organism survive
(e.g., birds leaving the nest, mother lion teaching cub to
hunt, cubs playing).

03AE8C68941C44B288244E59C1DA3844.description:
Describe how changes in the environment affect the
behavior of organisms (e.g., raccoons eating from trash
cans, squirrels hiding nuts, animals hibernating).

E0EC2702B0ED416F8D42239EE8ECD412.description:
Given
an environmental
change, identify a
behavioral change
that would help an
organism in that
environment.

BBFB137A0DE94F0CAA24DC2F3F4EDAC4.description:
Identify
a trait as either a
learned behavior
or an inherited
physical trait.

8A2FA28C7D6F4419AAFFFAB9A64A0B42.description:
Identify
one observable
way an offspring
resembles a
parent.

6C2BAC909B99452B94AD3BD327EADA61.description:
Match
an environmental
change to a potential
behavioral change of
an organism.

4202C04FCBF5421CBC2C88DF2E8A036C.description:
Sort a
set of given traits
as either learned
behaviors or inherited
physical traits.

B9B5591891C749BD9D2EC7F5669F7BD6.description:
Identify
similar inherited
physical traits that
can be observed in a
parent and offspring.

ED05FFB6850943788C48857E4FC212AB.description:
Explain
how a change in
an environment
can affect a
behavior of an
organism in that
environment.

4B73476D65814F4092FDEBA75495AFD1.description:
Explain
why a given trait is
learned behavior
or an inherited.

47C7FC90A0EB4CAA845F1B259A1FF736.description:
Explain why you
can expect the
offspring to have
similar physical
traits to the parent.

820F49BEE24F453E8833DE31B694EDB4.description:
Offspring resemble
their parents and each other.
Individual organisms inherit
many traits from their parents
indicating a reliable way to
transfer information from one
generation to the next. Some
behavioral traits are learned
through interactions with the
environment and are not
inherited.

7A53DBDEDEA549C38A49F316ED838968.description:
Identify behaviors as being conservative or wasteful (e.g.,
water running while brushing teeth or turning it off).

4BD0B3704CB94B65B273AC441A05392C.description:
Classify behaviors as being conservative or wasteful (e.g.,
only taking as many paper towels as you actually need).

3EE2EFDD283A42CEB43E51E6BF4F083A.description: State one way to conserve a given resource.

6C0F138D45174584B375D580A768FF6B.description:
Sort behaviors as contributions to conservation or wasteful
efforts.

FC92E3DCBD9C4F398E804798A5222F7A.description: Explain a way to conserve a given resource.

AE49BF4D2BDC47FAA5AF50108C726815.description:
Compare data on two means of conservation and choose
the more effective.

3618A3C8B4FA43DB8A26AAC4BAC4B6F7.description:
Identify
a way to conserve
a given resource.

8DAE1DEE0EDD4BA290B2F24996B83879.description:
Match a
limited resource to a
means to conserve
it (e.g., fresh water
can be conserved by
taking short showers).

845F0BBEAC05444BB429E78283372B3C.description:
Explain
a way to conserve
a given resource.

32E1D33667484762878313F131B0DF0C.description:
Some of Earth’s
resources are limited. Some
of Earth’s resources become
limited due to overuse and/
or contamination. Reducing
resource use, decreasing
waste and/or pollution,
recycling, and reusing
can help conserve these
resources.

965AB0DB8DA948FBA2900752ADC20314.description:
Identify a variety of renewable energy resources using
children’s literature or media.

308DBF82909E42B88D236DD4D0F02293.description:
Identify a variety of nonrenewable energy resources using
children’s literature or media.

4068452F85C742FDB167D68D12F96A51.description: Categorize resources as renewable or nonrenewable.

F20AED49B6044A5993CB58C03EAA0670.description:
Explain how renewable resources work to produce energy
(e.g., wind turbine using wind, solar panels, Niagara Falls
producing hydroelectricity).

639C237EA51C4144AC8D2A9AD86E55B5.description:
Explain how nonrenewable resources work to produce
energy (e.g., coal engine on a train, natural gas in a
stove).

A558D6CE71EB42DE8E4E66627429429F.description:
Given a resource explain why it is renewable or
nonrenewable.

2001D5A6E8744BA9B81A71560C6A9BEB.description:
Identify
a resource as
renewable or
nonrenewable.

F911AC9546914DD3BF47B624348EE6DD.description:
Sort
resources into
categories of
renewable and
nonrenewable.

2AAA596BE7934BDC994500C9F75F7FA2.description:
Explain
why a resource
is renewable or
nonrenewable.

6A95447C904C4A07AEF422844B4374F0.description:
Earth’s resources
can be used for energy.
Renewable energy
resources—such as wind,
water or solar energy—can
be replenished within a short
amount of time by natural
processes. Nonrenewable
energy is a finite resource,
such as natural gas, coal
or oil, which cannot be
replenished in a short amount
of time.

676B54A097ED49BBB8A3AC713C0A31F3.description: Note: Properties of materials were introduced in K.PS.1.

1BC3B08C4E684D88830E11357536BE12.description:
Identify characteristics of rocks (e.g., color, texture, crystal
size).

99320B0392B946CCB44260CF25A29D56.description:
Identify characteristics of different soil samples (e.g.,
texture, color, moisture).

33CBAB86D78C4DD881643D474912B9A5.description:
List the things that make up soil (e.g., pieces of rock,
organic material, water, air).

D9B849157CC549EB8AE254B5C2169618.description: Sort a group of rocks by a given characteristic.

6D37E20DA0834830BE6E3BD037719A2E.description:
Describe the similarities and differences between two
rocks.

8288C225BAB64B07BF0E2A44688D493A.description:
Compare the rate water passes through samples of
different rocks and soils.

08E11DCD4F70495ABBB2BC5A3690E562.description:
Recognize that different types of rocks are formed in
different ways.

84EA8388E1CB42E3BDF42B9C2CC43B52.description:
Identify
one characteristic
of a rock.

8A1CE7BB02B84064BB4F30DCC5B3F964.description:
Identify
the non-living
components of soil.

9603C85A6FCF4FFFB97BB201266A0DD4.description:
Sort rocks
by a given observable
characteristic (e.g.,
texture, color,
hardness).

47DAED2D423049998B3E5403613CF0FD.description:
Identify
the organic and nonliving components of
soil.

1027248DD42349EFA2974269DA47835D.description:
Identify
one way that rock
can form.

B36BA917BA134DB7BCA953CE079C8501.description:
Sort
and classify
rocks by specific
characteristics.

132A48F30C0D436786EC18762D2C7397.description:
Identify
a measurable
component of
soil (e.g., water,
particle size,
weight).

D84966B700B54C5DAB1A4921E8BE1493.description:
Earth’s nonliving
resources have specific
properties. Soil is composed
of pieces of rock, organic
material, water, and air and
has characteristics that can
be measured and observed.
Use the term “soil,” not
“dirt.” Dirt and soils are not
synonymous. Rocks have
specific characteristics that
allow them to be sorted and
compared. Rocks form in
different ways. Air and water
are also nonliving resources.
Note: Rock classification
is not the focus for this
grade level; this is found in
grade 6. At this grade, the
observable characteristics
of rocks are used to sort or
compare, rather than formally
classification.
